A '''nonchord tone''' ('''NCT'''), '''nonharmonic tone''', or '''embellishing tone''' is a [[Musical note|note]] in a piece of [[music]] or [[song]] that is not part of the implied or expressed [[chord (music)|chord]] set out by the [[harmony|harmonic]] framework. In contrast, a '''chord tone''' is a note that is a part of the [[diatonic function|functional]] chord (see: [[factor (chord)]]). Nonchord tones are most often discussed in the context of the [[common practice period]] of [[classical music]], but they can be used in the analysis of other types of [[tonality|tonal music]] as well, such as Western [[popular music]].
Nonchord tones are often categorized as ''accented nonchord tones'' and ''unaccented nonchord tones'' depending on whether the dissonance occurs on an accented or unaccented [[Beat (music)|beat]] (or part of a beat).
Over time, some musical styles assimilated chord types outside of the common-practice style. In these chords, tones that might normally be considered nonchord tones are viewed as chord tones, such as the seventh of a [[minor seventh chord]]. For example, in 1940s-era [[bebop jazz]], playing an F{{music|#}} with a C{{music|7 chord}} chord, woud be considered a chord tones if the chord were analyzed as C<sup>7({{music|#}}11)</sup>. In European classical music, "[t]he greater use of dissonance from period to period as a result of the dialectic of linear/vertical forces led to gradual normalization of [[Ninth chord|ninth]], [[Eleventh chord|eleventh]], and [[Thirteenth chord|thirteenth chords]] [in analysis and theory]; each additional non-chord tone above the foundational triad became frozen into the chordal mass."<ref>"Debussy and the Crisis of Tonality", p.72. Author(s): Roland Nadeau. Source: Music Educators Journal, Vol. 66, No. 1, (Sep., 1979), pp. 69-73. Published by: MENC: The National Association for Music Education.</ref>
== Theory == {{Image frame|content=<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond" override_midi="Lassus - Beatus vir in sapientia, mm 23-24.mid"> { << 
ew StaffGroup << 
ew Staff << \set Staff.midiInstrument = #"voice oohs" \clef treble 	ime 4/2 elative c'' { \clef treble 	ime 4/2 b2 c1 bes2 a1 g2 a } >> 
ew Staff << \set Staff.midiInstrument = #"voice oohs" \clef treble 	ime 4/2 
ew Voice elative c' { r2 e f g~ g ^\markup { \center-align { " prep. sus. res." } } f e d4 e } >> >> >> } </score>|width=340|caption=A 2-3 suspension in [[Lassus]]'s ''Beatus vir in sapientia'', mm. 23–24, showing the [[preparation (music)|preparation]], suspension (a type of nonchord tone), and [[resolution (music)|resolution]].}}Chord and nonchord tones are defined by their membership (or lack of membership) in a chord: "The pitches which make up a chord are called ''chord-tones'': any other pitches are called ''non-chord-tones''."<ref>Kroepel, Bob (1993). ''Mel Bay Creative Keyboard's Deluxe Encyclopedia of Piano Chords: A Complete Study of Chords and How to Use Them'', p.8. {{ISBN|978-0-87166-579-9}}. Emphasis original.</ref> They are also defined by the time at which they sound: "''Nonharmonic tones'' are pitches that sound along with a chord but are not chord pitches."<ref name="Benward & Saker">Benward & Saker (2003). ''Music: In Theory and Practice'', Vol. I, p.92. Seventh Edition. {{ISBN|978-0-07-294262-0}}.</ref> For example, if an excerpt from a piece of music implies or uses a C-major chord, then the notes C, E and G are members of that chord, while any other note played at that time (e.g., notes such as F{{music|#}}) is a nonchord tone. Such tones are most obvious in [[homophony|homophonic]] music but occur at least as frequently in [[counterpoint|contrapuntal music]].
According to ''Music in Theory and Practice,'' "Most nonharmonic tones are [[Consonance and dissonance|dissonant]] and create [[interval (music)|intervals]] of a second, fourth or seventh",<ref name="Benward & Saker"/> which are required to [[resolution (music)|resolve]] to a chord tone in conventional ways. If the note fails to resolve until the next change of harmony, it may instead create a [[seventh chord]] or [[extended chord]]. While theoretically in a three-note chord, there are nine possible nonchord tones in [[equal temperament]], in practice nonchord tones are usually in the prevailing [[key (music)|key]]. Augmented and diminished intervals are also considered dissonant, and all nonharmonic tones are measured from the [[bass note]], or lowest note sounding in the chord except in the case of nonharmonic bass tones.<ref name="Benward & Saker"/>
Nonharmonic tones generally occur in a pattern of three pitches, of which the nonharmonic tone is the center:<ref name="Benward & Saker"/> :{| style="text-align: center;" |- | Chord tone || – || Nonchord tone || – || Chord tone |- |[[Preparation (music)|Preparation]]|| – ||[[Consonance and dissonance|Dissonance]]|| – ||[[Resolution (music)|Resolution]] |- |}
Nonchord tones are categorized by how they are used. The most important distinction is whether they occur on a strong or weak [[beat (music)|beat]] and are thus either accented or unaccented nonchord tones.<ref name="Benward & Saker"/> They are also distinguished by their direction of approach and departure and the voice or voices in which they occur and the number of notes they contain.
==Unaccented== ===Anticipation===<!--[[Anticipation (music)]] redirects directly here.--> An ''anticipation'' (ANT) occurs when this note is approached by [[Step (music)|step]] and then remains the same. It is basically a note of the second chord played early. In the example below, the dissonant B in bar 1 is approached by step and resolves when that same pitch becomes a chord tone in bar 2.
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \stemUp \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 c4 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red b b2 } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e2 d } >> 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <c g'>2 g'  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
A ''[[portamento]]'' is the late Renaissance precursor to the [[#Anticipation|anticipation]],<ref>Benward & Saker (2009). ''Music in Theory and Practice'', Vol. II, p.8. {{ISBN|978-0-07-310188-0}}.</ref> though today it refers to a [[glissando]].
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond" override_midi="Portamento.mid"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << elative c'' { \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/2 \partial2 d2~ d c4 d e f g e } >> 
ew Staff << elative c'' { \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/2 \partial2 b2~ b4 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red a a2 g e } >> >> </score>
=== Neighbor tone<!--[[Neighbor note]] and [[neighbor tone]] redirect directly here.--> === A ''neighbor tone'' (NT) or ''auxiliary note'' (AUX) is a nonchord tone that passes stepwise from a chord tone directly above or below it (which frequently causes the NT to create dissonance with the chord) and resolves to the same chord tone:
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemUp c4 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red d c2 } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e2 e } >> 
ew Staff << elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <c g'>2 <c g'>  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
In practice and analysis, neighboring tones are sometimes differentiated depending upon whether or not they are lower or higher than the chord tones surrounding them. A neighboring tone that is a step higher than the surrounding chord tones is called an ''upper neighboring tone'' or an ''upper auxiliary note'' while a neighboring tone that is a step lower than the surrounding chord tones is a ''lower neighboring tone'' or ''lower auxiliary note''. However, following [[Heinrich Schenker]]'s usage in ''[[Free Composition]]'', some authors reserve the term "neighbor note" to the lower neighbor a [[half step]] below the main note.<ref name=Grove>{{GroveOnline|title=Non-harmonic note|author=William Drabkin|access-date=June 4, 2016}}</ref>
The German term ''Nebennote'' is a somewhat broader category, including all nonchord tones approached from the main note by step.<ref name=Grove/>
===Escape tone=== An ''escape tone'' (ET) or ''echappée'' is a particular type of unaccented incomplete neighbor tone that is approached stepwise from a chord tone and resolved by a skip in the opposite direction back to the harmony.
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \stemUp \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 c4 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red d b2 } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e2 d } >> 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <c g'>2 g'  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
===Passing tone=== A ''passing tone'' (PT) or ''passing note'' is a nonchord tone prepared by a chord tone a step above or below it and resolved by continuing in the same direction stepwise to the next chord tone (which is either part of the same chord or of the next chord in the harmonic progression).
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemUp c4 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red d e2 } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e2 e } >> 
ew Staff << elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <c g'>2 <c g'>  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
Where two nonchord tones are before the resolution they are ''double passing tones'' or ''double passing notes''.
==Accented==
===Passing tone=== As with above but on an accented beat.
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemUp g1 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red f2 e } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e1 c } >> 
ew Staff << elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <c g'>1 <c g'>  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
===Neighbor tone=== A neighbor tone where you step up or down from the chord tone, and then move back to the chord tone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musictheory.net/lessons/53|title=Nonharmonic Tones}}</ref>
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemUp g1 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red a2 g } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e1 e } >> 
ew Staff << elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <c g'>1 <c g'>  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
===Suspension and retardation===<!-- This section is linked from [[Goldberg Variations]] and [[Syncope (music)]], see [[MOS:SECTIONS]] --> {{Anchor|Suspension}} {{quote|Endeavor, moreover, to introduce suspensions now in this voice, now in that, for it is incredible how much grace the melody acquires by this means. And every note which has a special function is rendered audible thereby.|[[Johann Joseph Fux]] (1725)<ref>Forte (1979), p.304.</ref>|}}A ''suspension'' (SUS) (sometimes referred to as a ''syncope''<ref name="Jonas96">Jonas (1982), p.96.</ref>) occurs when the harmony shifts from one chord to another, but one or more notes of the first chord (the preparation) are either temporarily held over into or are played again against the second chord (against which they are nonchord tones called the ''suspension'') before resolving downwards to a chord tone by step (the resolution). The whole process is called a ''suspension'' as well as the specific nonchord tone(s).
Suspensions may be further described with two numbers: (1) the [[Interval (music)|interval]] between the suspended note and the [[bass note]] and (2) the interval between the resolution and the bass note. The most common suspensions are 4-3 suspension, 7-6 suspension, or 9-8 suspension. Note that except for the 9-8 suspensions, the numbers are typically referred to using the [[Simple interval|simple intervals]], so for instance, if intervals are actually an 11th and a 10th (the first example below), you would typically call it a ''4-3 suspension''. If the bass note is suspended, then the interval is calculated between the bass and the part that is most dissonant with it, often resulting in a 2-3 suspension.'''<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/51613969|title=Tonal Harmony|last=Kostka|first=Stefan|last2=Payne|first2=Dorothy|date=2004|publisher=McGraw-Hill|others=|year=|isbn=0072852607|edition=5th|location=Boston|pages=172|oclc=51613969}}</ref>'''
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \stemUp \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 c1^~ \once \override NoteHead.color = #red c2^\markup { " 4 - 3" } b2 c1^~ \once \override NoteHead.color = #red c2^\markup { " 7 - 6" } b2 c1^~ \once \override NoteHead.color = #red c2^\markup { " 9 - 8" } b2 c1 d^\markup { " 2 - 3" } } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e1 d e d e d e d } >> 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c' { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemUp g1 s g f g g g g } 
ew Voice elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemDown c1 g'  ar "||" c, d  ar "||" c b  ar "||" c_~ \once \override NoteHead.color = #red c2 b  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
Suspensions must resolve downwards. If a tied note is prepared like a suspension but resolves upwards, it is called a ''retardation''. Common retardations include 2-3 and 7-8 retardations.
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \stemUp \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 c1^~ \once \override NoteHead.color = #red c2^\markup { " 2 - 3" } d2 c1^~ \once \override NoteHead.color = #red c2^\markup { " 7 - 8" } d2 } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e1 d e d } >> 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <c g'>1 <b g'>  ar "||" <c g'> <d f>  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
Decorated suspensions are common and consist of [[#Portamento|portamento]]s or double eighth notes, the second being a lower neighbor tone.
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \stemUp \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 c1^~ \once \override NoteHead.color = #red c4 b8 a b2 } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e1 d } >> 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c' { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemUp g1 s } 
ew Voice elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemDown c1 g'  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
A chain of suspensions constitutes the fourth species of [[counterpoint]]; an example may be found in the second movement of [[Arcangelo Corelli]]'s [[Christmas Concerto (Corelli)|''Christmas Concerto'']].[[File:Corelli Xmas Concerto 2nd movement.png|thumb|center|500px|Corelli's ''Christmas Concerto'', 2nd movement. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RydMnTCwJvQ&t=1m47s Listen]]]
===Appoggiatura=== An ''[[appoggiatura]]'' (APP) is a type of accented incomplete neighbor tone approached skip-wise from one chord tone and resolved stepwise to another chord tone ("overshooting" the chord tone).
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \stemUp \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 g1 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red c2 b } 
ew Voice elative c' { \stemDown e1 d } >> 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c' { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemUp g1 s } 
ew Voice elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \stemDown c1 g'  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
===Nonharmonic bass<!--[[Nonharmonic bass]] redirects directly here.-->=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Nonharmonic bass example 1.png|thumb|Nonharmonic bass: F, below a C major chord. {{audio|Nonharmonic bass example 1.mid|Play}}]] --> ''Nonharmonic bass'' notes are bass notes that are not a member of the chord below which they are written. Examples include the [[Elektra chord]].<ref>Lawrence Kramer. "Fin-de-siècle Fantasies: Elektra, Degeneration and Sexual Science", ''Cambridge Opera Journal'', Vol. 5, No. 2. (Jul., 1993), pp. 141-165.</ref> An example of a nonharmonic bass from the third movement of [[Igor Stravinsky|Stravinsky]]'s ''[[Symphony of Psalms]]''.<ref>Andriessen, Louis & Schönberger, Elmer (2006). ''The Apollonian Clockwork: On Stravinsky''. Amsterdam University Press. {{ISBN|9789053568569}}.</ref>
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> { \override Score.TimeSignature #'stencil = ##f 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << elative c' { \stemUp \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <f a f' c'>1 } >> 
ew Staff << elative c, { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \ottava #-1 \once \override NoteHead.color = #red <bes bes'>1 } >> >> } </score>
==Involving more than three notes==
===Changing tones=== ''[[Changing tones]]'' (CT) are two successive nonharmonic tones. A chord tone steps to a nonchord tone which skips to another nonchord tone which leads by step to a chord tone, often the same chord tone. They may imply neighboring tones with a missing or implied note in the middle. Also called ''double neighboring tones'' or ''neighbor group''.<ref name="Benward & Saker"/>
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \voiceOne c2 \override NoteHead.color = #red b4 d \override NoteHead.color = #black c1 } 
ew Voice elative c'' { \voiceTwo a1 g } >> 
ew Staff << elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <f c'>1 <e c'>  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
===Pedal point=== Another form of nonchord tone is a [[pedal point|''pedal point'']] or ''pedal tone'' (PD) or ''note'', almost always the [[tonic (music)|tonic]] or [[dominant (music)|dominant]], which is held through a series of chord changes. The pedal point is almost always in the lowest voice (the term originates from [[organ (music)|organ]] playing), but it may be in an upper voice; then it may be called an ''inverted pedal''. It may also be between the upper and lower voices, in which case it is called an ''internal pedal''.
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond" override_midi="Pedalpoint.mid"> 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c' { \clef treble \key c \major 	ime 4/4 <d g b>2 <d f b> <c e c'> <cis e bes'> <d fis a> <es fis c'> <d g c> <d f b> } >> 
ew Staff << elative c { \clef bass \key c \major 	ime 4/4 \override NoteHead.color = #red g1~ g~ g~ g  ar "||" } >> >> </score>
==Chromatic nonharmonic tone== A ''chromatic nonharmonic tone'' is a nonharmonic tone that is [[diatonic and chromatic|chromatic]], or outside of the [[key (music)|key]] and creates [[semitone|half-step]] motion. The use of which, especially ''chromatic appoggiaturas'' and ''chromatic passing tones'', increased in the [[Romantic music|Romantic Period]].<ref name="B&S217">Benward & Saker (2009), p.217-18.</ref> The example below shows chromatic nonharmonic tones (in red) in the first four measures of [[Frédéric Chopin]]'s [[Preludes (Chopin)|Prelude No. 21, op. 28]].<ref name="B&S217" />
:<score vorbis="1" lang="lilypond" override_midi="Chopin - op. 28, no. 21, mm.1-4.mid"> { 
ew PianoStaff << 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c'' { 	empo "Cantabile" \clef treble \key bes \major 	ime 3/4 \override DynamicLineSpanner.staff-padding = #2.5 f2.\p( d2 \acciaccatura { f8 } es4 d2. g,2.) } >> 
ew Staff << 
ew Voice elative c { \clef bass \key bes \major 	ime 3/4 \override NoteHead.color = #red \hide Stem s4 e8 s4. s4 e8 s4. s4 fis8 b s4 s4 fis8 b s4 } 
ew Voice elative c, { \clef bass \key bes \major 	ime 3/4 bes8\<\sustainOn_[ f''^( <e g>\sustainOff <es a> <d bes'> <c c'>]\! bes8\<\sustainOn_[) <f' d'>^( <e g>\sustainOff <es a> <d bes'> bes]\! es,8\<\sustainOn_[) g'^( <fis a>\sustainOff <f b> <es c'> <d d'>]\! c8\<\sustainOn_[) <g' es'>^( <fis a>\sustainOff <f b> <es c'> <c es'>])\! } >> >> } </score>
==See also== * [[Ornament (music)|Ornament]] * [[Non-harmonic arpeggio]]
==Sources== {{reflist}}
{{Consonance and dissonance}}

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|date=June 2013}} {{unreferenced|date=June 2013}} {{Orphan|date=September 2014}} }} [[File:Poznań, Wszechsłowiański Zjazd Śpiewaczy 1929 - 03.jpg|thumb|The opening of the congress at the newly built [[Stadion Edmunda Szyca]]]] [[File:Poznań, Wszechsłowiański Zjazd Śpiewaczy 1929 - 02.jpg|thumb|Czechoslovakian singers salute the President of Poland, [[Ignacy Mościcki]], during the military parade]] The '''Panslavic Congress of Singers''' – the international assembly of the choirs and associations of singers which took place in [[Poznań]] within 18–21 of May 1929 during the commencing of the [[Polish General Exhibition]]. It was connected with the First Polish Music Festival (21–29 of May 1929). The idea of the congress was initiated by the [[Greater Poland]]’s Singers Association and Slovak Singers’ Union under the conception of non-political binding of the [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] nations by dint of the culture. Choirs from various regions of [[Poland]] and [[Polish diaspora]], groups from [[Czechoslovakia]], [[Yugoslavia]] and [[Bulgaria]] have participated in it massively. Altogether over 17 000 singers have sung (other sources say about 18 000 or 20 000). 8 thousand men under leadership of professor [[Władysław Raczkowski]] sang the hymn [[Gaude Mater Polonia]]. The performance of Ojczyzna by [[Feliks Nowowiejski]] with his companionship of ten [[brass band]]s have caused the peculiar appealing of the audience. The number of people singing at once at the day of the opening is approximated to 12 000 or 13 000. The souvenir after the Congress was the first ''Slavic Linden'' which was supposed to symbolise the unity and fraternity of the Slavic nations. It was planted by the participants on 21 May 1929 at 7 p.m. It was known to be located near the nearby opera, which now exists as the [[Henryk Wieniawski]] Park; Other sources say about [[Adam Mickiewicz]] Park. It was surrounded by 4 masts and every each had the banner of Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Poland. It was intended to ultimately place it in the planned Slavic park. Around the linden, on the rails, there was a Polish inscription: {{Quotation| Lipa słowiańska
zasadzona na pamiątkę I wszechsłowiańskiego
zjazdu śpiewaczego
w dniach 18.5.–22.5.1929 | | |width=70% |align=left |text=center }} {{clear}} Which translates to {{Quotation| Slavic linden
planted in memory of the first panslavic
congress of singers
days 18.5.–22.5.1929 | | |width=70% |align=left |text=center }} {{clear}} The tree was cut by the [[Nazis]]. == Bibliography == * {{pl icon}} Krystyna Winowicz, ''Narodowe i patriotyczne idee wielkopolskiego ruchu śpiewaczego'', KAW, Poznań, 1982, ss. 33-34 == External links == * {{pl icon}} red. [[Henryk Opieński]]: [http://www.wbc.poznan.pl/dlibra/doccontent?id=70902 Księga Pamiątkowa Wszechsłowiańskiego Zjazdu Śpiewaczego i Festiwalu Muzyki Polskiej w Poznaniu w maju 1929 (w: WBC)], wyd. Wielkopolski Związek Kół Śpiewaczych, Poznań 1929 * {{pl icon}} [http://www.wbc.poznan.pl/dlibra/doccontent?id=236164 Wszechsłowiański Zjazd Śpiewaczy 18-21 maja 1929, Program (w: WBC)] [[Category:History of Poznań]] [[Category:Slavic culture]] [[Category:1929 in Poland]] [[Category:1929 in music]] [[Category:1929 conferences]]

revision.text:
The '''Pan American Nikkei Association''', the English-language name of the ''Asociación Panamericana Nikkei'', is a multi-national, non-governmental organization with membership from [[Argentina]], [[Bolivia]], [[Brazil]], [[Canada]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Japan]], [[Mexico]], [[Paraguay]], [[Peru]], [[Dominican Republic]], [[Uruguay]], [[Venezuela]], [[United States]].<ref name="pana1">National Association of Japanese Canadians: [http://www.najc.ca/thenandnow/relations_pana.php PANA overview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218195725/http://www.najc.ca/thenandnow/relations_pana.php |date=2009-02-18 }}</ref>
==History==
In 1981, Mexican ''[[Nikkei people|Nikkei]]'' organized the first convention; and its character was summarized in a slogan: "Let us be better citizens in our continent" (''Seamos mejores ciudadanos en nuestro contiente'').<ref>Kikumura-Yano, Akemi ''et al.'' (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=MXTOAw1A_ucC&pg=RA1-PA219&dq=Pan+American+nikkei+association&client=firefox-a ''Encyclopedia of Japanese Descendants in the Americas: An Illustrated History of the Nikkei.'' p. 219.]</ref> Delegates from Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Peru and the United States joined the Mexican organizers for this initial meeting in Mexico City.<ref name="apa1">Asociación Peruano Japonesa: [http://www.apj.org.pe/yamaguchi/historia Asociación Yamaguchi Kenjin del Perú]</ref>
==Presidents== Presidents have a maximum term of two years. Could be reelected one term *2017-2019 Mr. Fernando Suenaga from Peru *2013-2017 Mr. Arturo Yoshimoto from USA *2009-2013 Mr. Noritaka Yano from Brazil *2005-2009 Mr. Felix Kasamatsu from Paraguay *2001-2005 Mr. Kazunori Kosaka from Argentina *1999-2001 Mr. Carlos Kasuga from Mexico *1995-1999 Mr. Luis Sakoda from Peru *1981-1995 Mr. Carlos Kasuga from Mexico
==Biennial conventions== PANA conventions are an opportunity for the ''nikkei'' from North and South America to share and discuss issues and events with cultural, historical, political and economic and political consequences which transcend national borders. These formal gatherings foster an exchange of ideas and create a forum for personal interaction with delegates from different countries.
The biennial conventions are intended to helps promotes closer relationships amongst the Nikkei organizations in the Western Hemisphere. PANA convention are planned in alternating locations amongst North, Central and South American countries.<ref name="pana1"/>
The Conventions of the Association of Pan American Nikkei (COPANI) have enlarged across the span of time: * 1981—The 1st convention in Mexico City, Mexico brought together delegates from six countries.<ref name="apa1"/> * 1983—The 2nd convention (COPANI II) was held in Peru.<ref name="masterson">Masterson, Daniel M. (2003). [https://books.google.com/books?id=0FeqfIcY358C&pg=PA234&lpg=PA234&dq=Pan+American+nikkei+association&source=web&ots=P3SWQNEOhL&sig=DISK7JM4ziBgClkuejJLaNgut_o ''The Japanese in Latin America,'' p. 234.]</ref> * 1985—The 3rd convention (COPANI III) was in Brazil.<ref name="masterson"/> * 1987—The 4th convention (COPANI IV) took place in Argentina.<ref name="masterson"/> * 1989—The 5th assembly (COPANI V) was held in the United States at Los Angeles.<ref name="masterson"/> * 1991—The 6th convention (COPANI VI) was hosted by Paraguay's ''Nikkei.''<ref name="masterson"/> * 1993—The 7th gathering (COPANI VII) in Vancouver, Canada brought together 400 delegates from 11 countries.<ref name="pana1"/> * 1995—The 8th assembly (COPANI VIII) in Lima, Peru.<ref name="masterson"/> * 1997—The 9th convention (COPANI IX) took place in Mexico.<ref name="masterson"/> * 1999—The 10th convention (COPANI X) was held in Chile.<ref name="masterson"/> * 2001—The 11th convention (COPANI XI) was hosted by the United States ''Nikkei'' at New York City.<ref name="masterson"/> * 2003—The 12th convention (COPANI XII) was hosted by the Bolivian membership.<ref name="masterson"/> * 2005—The 13th convention (COPANI XIII) in Vancouver, Canada was actively supported by the National Association of Japanese Canadians.<ref name="pana1"/> * 2007—The 14th ''Convencion Panamericana Nikkei'' (COPANI XIV) in São Paulo, Brazil was organized in part by ''Zaidan Hojin Kaigai Nikkeijin Kyokai.'' Approximately 700 attended.<ref>Asociación Panamericana Nikkei: [http://www.copani.org/]; [http://www.jadesas.or.jp/taikai/02houkoku48.html 第48回海外日系人大会]</ref> * 2009—The 15th Convention(COPANI XV) was held in the city of Montevideo, Uruguay *2011 - The 16th Copani (COPANI XVI) was held in Cancun, Mexico under the leadership of young Nikkeis from Mexico. *2013 - The 17th Copani (COPANI XVII) was held in Buenos Aires, Argentina on September 12–14, 2013. Approximately 500 Attended. Supported by the Centro Nikkei Argentino and a youth staff of approximately 80 young Argentinian Nikkeis. *2015 - The 18th Copani (COPANI XVIII) was held in Domican Republic on August 6–8, 2015. Sponsored by FUNDONI ( Fundacion Dominicana Nikkei - Foundation of the Dominican Nikkei) See www.copani.org [http://www.copani.org/] *2017 - The 19th Copani (COPANI XIX) was held in Lima - Peru in 2017 Theme" Building our Future" (Spanish "Contruyendo Nuestro Futuro") *2019 - The 20th Copani (COPANI XX) will be Held in the USA - San Francisco, California *2021 - The 21st Copani (COPANI XXI) will be held in Asuncion - Paraguay *2023 - The 22nd Copani (COPANI XXII) will be held in Vancouver - Canada to be confirmed. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== * Kasamatsu, Emi. (2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=jDB1AAAAMAAJ&q=Pan+American+nikkei+association&dq=Pan+American+nikkei+association&lr=&client=firefox-a&pgis=1 ''Historia de la Asociación Panamericana Nikkei: Presencia e inmigración japonesas en las Américas.''] Asunción: Servilibro. {{ISBN|978-99925-921-4-4}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/oclc/68741080 OCLC 68741080] * Kikumura-Yano, Akemi and Daniel K. Inouye. (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=MXTOAw1A_ucC&dq=Pan+American+nikkei+association&client=firefox-a&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0 ''Encyclopedia of Japanese Descendants in the Americas: An Illustrated History of the Nikkei.'']. Walnut Creek, California: Rowman Altamira. {{ISBN|978-0-7591-0149-4}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/oclc/48965106 OCLC 48965106] * Masterson, Daniel M. and Sayaka Funada-Classen. (2003). [https://books.google.com/books?id=0FeqfIcY358C&dq=Pan+American+nikkei+association&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0 ''The Japanese in Latin America.''] Urbana: [[University of Illinois Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-252-07144-7}}
==External links== * [http://www.copani.org/ Asociación Panamericana Nikkei web page] * [http://www.apj.org.pe/quienes-somos/nosotros Asociación Peruano Japonesa web site]
[[Category:Japanese diaspora in North America]] [[Category:Overseas Japanese organisations]] [[Category:Community building]]

Launched in 2006 as an annual fine arts competition for emerging artists in the [[United Arab Emirates]], under the [[patronage]] of [[Manal bint Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]], President of Dubai Women Establishment and the founder of Dubai Ladies Club, wife of [[Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan|Mansour bin Zayed Al Nayhan]], Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Presidential Affairs, UAE.<ref>{{Cite web|title = H.H. Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed honours winners of The Sheikha Manal Young Artist Award|url = http://gulftimes.ae/h-h-sheikh-mansour-bin-zayed-honours-winners-of-the-sheikha-manal-young-artist-award/|accessdate = 2015-06-11}}</ref> The prize money of the awards totals to USD 110,000 and divided into four main categories: [[Fine art|Fine Art]], [[Photography]], [[Multimedia]] and [[Design]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sheikha Manal Young Artist Award competition now open {{!}} The National|url = http://www.thenational.ae/blogs/the-art-blog/sheikha-manal-young-artist-award-competition-now-open|accessdate = 2015-06-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Mohammed visits Sheikha Manal Young Artist Award exhibition|url = http://www.emirates247.com/news/government/mohammed-visits-sheikha-manal-young-artist-award-exhibition-2015-01-17-1.576865|accessdate = 2015-06-11|first = Wam|last = Wam}}</ref>
==Judges== The award is juried by a different panel of industry professionals and senior artists every year. 50 artworks are shortlisted from the online open call applications, followed by the declaration of the winners at the gala award ceremony.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Winners of Shaikha Manal Young Artist Award 2012 honoured|url = http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/general/winners-of-shaikha-manal-young-artist-award-2012-honoured-1.1122718|website = gulfnews.com|accessdate = 2015-06-11}}</ref>
*2006: [[Hassan Sharif]], [[Najat Makki|Dr.Najat Makki]], [[Mohammed Kazem]], William Lawrie, Ian Redelinghuys, Dr. Mazen Asfour, Nelda Gildam. *2008: [[Najat Makki|Dr.Najat Makki]], Jassim Al Awadhi, Nazeem Shafi, Patricia Mills, Kimberly Lund. *2009: Sheikha Lateefa bint Maktoum, Salwa Mikdadi, Judith Greer, Jassim Al Awadhi. *2010: Antonia Carver, [[Jack Persekian]], Jassim Al Awadhi, [[Sultan Sooud Al-Qassemi|Sultan Sooud Al Qassemi]], William Lawrie. *2011: Hoor Al Qasimi, Rami Farouk, Hala Khayat, Patricia Mills. *2012: Khalil Abdulwahid, Rami Farook, [[Ebtisam AbdulAziz|Ebtisam Abdulaziz]], Ramin Salsali. *2013: Antonia Carver, Maisa Al Qassimi, Marjan Farjan, [[Wafa Hasher Al Maktoum]].
==Winners== *2006: Sarah Ayoub Agha, Natalie Penderis, Nuha Hassan Asad Ali Hussain, Muna Al Ali, Roshni Armanani. *2008: Sarah Abdul Rahman Saifaei, Nazanin Irani, Nadia Hamidi, Darwin H. Guevarra, Raji Salem Al Sharif. *2009: Evan Paul Collisson, Rebecca Rendell, Nawal Khoory, Maitha Hilal Bin Demithan, Zainab Al Haj Yahya, Noor Abdullah, Afra Hilal Khalifan Bin Dhaher, Ayesha Salahuddin Al Janahi, Altamash Urooj. *2010: Fatima Mahuiddin, Zara Mahnmoud, Mohammed Hisham Hindash, Hamad Alansari, Aya Atoui, Saher Sheikh, Nishad Mohammed. *2011: Walid Al Wawi, Asma Belhamar, Raudha Al Ghurair, Omar Aly Mohamed, Bassim A.Eskander, Jetshri Bhadviya, Razan Daoud Khalaf, Lantian Xie, Deena Stevens, Arwa Al Absi Al Jundi. *2012: Saif Mhaisen, Amal Zainal Alkhaja, Nada Khalid Al Abdooli, Ali Aminu Monguno, Omnia El Afifi, Rasha Dakkak, Bao-Nhat Dinh Nguyen, Arwa Ramadan, Nargis Dhirani. *2013: Sarah Al Agroobi, Bahar Al Bahar, Nada Abu Shakra, Maitha Abdulla, Mohammed Shabanpoor, Fatma Fairooz, Hatem Hatem, Nasser Al Zayani, Sarah Al Agroobi, Tayma Bittard, Gabriella Gomez, Samar Idris, Bahar Al Bahar.
